MACV infection could completely block the MACV-triggered IFN response. at 6 h post-MACV infection, LASV coinfection suppressed MACV-induced IFN- protein expression by 95%. the highly pathogenic OW arenavirus LASV blocks host innate and adaptive immune responses and causes severe and often fatal diseases. MACV infection also induces IFN production in a lethal NHP model (19) we demonstrated that JUNV and MACV could activate IFN responses in human dendritic cells. results indicated that human dendritic cells were capable of detecting infections by JUNV and MACV. this observation is in accord with previous studies reporting that infection of murine dendritic cells with pathogenic JUNV isolates resulted in IFN production. the lung epithelial A549 cell line as a cell culture model might potentially facilitate study of the host response to arenavirus infection. however, data from study with A549 cells needs to be further validated in dendritic cells and macrophages. we also suggested that parenchymal cells, in addition to dendritic cells, could be the source of IFN production in vivo. the host IFN pathway responded more efficiently to infections by JUNV and MACV in human cells. the OW pathogenic arenavirus LASV readily elicited IFN responses. the inability of the IFN pathway to respond to LASV infection could possibly be due to either LASV active inhibition of the IFN pathway or evasion of host detection by the IFN pathway. the window for LASV inhibition as shown in Fig. 6 is unlikely due to differential entry kinetics of LASV and MACV. host cells more likely have detected a “danger signal” associated with MACV replication rather than an immediate early signal. otherwise, one would observe an early wave of IFN production, which is not the case. the impact of IFN or cytokines on virus infection and pathogenesis is not well understood. the race between the host immune response and virus replication begins very early during the course of viral infection. IFNs and cytokines also stimulate and regulate cell-mediated innate and adaptive immune responses. we find that IFNs are critical to control JUNV and MACV infections in murine systems. in an NHP model, an early peak of type I IFN production correlated with animal survival. fatal infection was characterized by a lack of early type I IFN production.
